questions.question: Which of the following best describes the anatomical location of the omohyoid muscle?
questions.short_explanation: The omohyoid extends from the scapula to the hyoid bone.
questions.long_explanation: The omohyoid muscle has two bellies — inferior and superior — connected by an intermediate tendon. It runs from the scapula to the hyoid bone and functions in depressing the hyoid during swallowing and speech.
questions.clinical_application: Palpating the omohyoid is challenging due to its depth and location. Its tension can contribute to anterior neck discomfort in some clients.
questions.source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.
options: From the scapula to the hyoid bone
From the clavicle to the mandible
From the sternum to the thyroid cartilage
From the occiput to the clavicle
questions.correctAnswer: From the scapula to the hyoid bone

questions.question: Which fascial structure anchors the intermediate tendon of the omohyoid to the clavicle?
questions.short_explanation: The intermediate tendon is held in place by a fascial sling.
questions.long_explanation: A fascial sling or loop at the clavicle holds the omohyoid’s intermediate tendon, allowing both bellies to work efficiently. This connection ensures stable movement of the hyoid bone during swallowing.
questions.clinical_application: Manual therapists should be aware of fascial continuity in the neck when applying myofascial release or treating tension headaches.
questions.source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

questions.question: What is the origin of the inferior belly of the omohyoid?
questions.short_explanation: It originates from the superior border of the scapula.
questions.long_explanation: The inferior belly of the omohyoid arises from the superior border of the scapula, near the suprascapular notch. This orientation helps in depressing and retracting the hyoid bone.
questions.clinical_application: Understanding its origin is crucial during neck and shoulder assessments, especially when tracking fascial lines.

questions.question: The omohyoid muscle helps stabilize which bone during swallowing?
questions.long_explanation: The omohyoid plays a stabilizing role for the hyoid bone, especially during swallowing and speaking. It assists other infrahyoid muscles in this function.
questions.clinical_application: Knowledge of hyoid stabilization aids massage therapists in treating anterior neck tension affecting speech or swallowing.

questions.question: What separates the omohyoid into its superior and inferior components?
questions.short_explanation: The intermediate tendon divides the muscle.
questions.long_explanation: The omohyoid consists of two distinct parts — superior and inferior bellies — which are connected by an intermediate tendon tethered to the clavicle by a fascial sling.
questions.clinical_application: Massage therapists should account for this bipartite structure when treating anterior neck or upper shoulder tension.
questions.source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

questions.question: In which fascial layer is the omohyoid most commonly embedded?
questions.short_explanation: It is located in the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.
questions.long_explanation: The omohyoid travels within the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia, which also encloses the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius. This layer provides support and separation from superficial structures.
questions.clinical_application: A working knowledge of fascial compartments helps therapists navigate layered tissue techniques in the neck.
questions.source_reference: Netter’s Atlas of Human Anatomy, 7th Ed.
options: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia
questions.correctAnswer: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia
